ai-sn24:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove.
ai-sn24:1.1.3_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:1.1.4_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
ai-sn24:1.2.1_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn24:1.2.1_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn24:1.2.1_2: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn24:1.2.2_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn24:1.3.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:1.3.2_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
ai-sn24:1.3.6_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:1.3.7_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
ai-sn24:1.3.11_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:1.3.13_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”
ai-sn24:1.3.14_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
ai-sn24:1.4.6_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

ai-sn24:1.4.9_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
ai-sn24:1.4.11_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:1.4.13_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:1.4.15_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”
ai-sn24:1.4.16_0: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
ai-sn24:1.5.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, they’ve given up doubts regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
ai-sn24:1.5.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:1.5.3_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn24:2.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:2.1.3_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:2.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:2.1.5_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:2.1.6_0: someone regards it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
ai-sn24:2.1.10_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:2.1.11_0: someone regards it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
ai-sn24:2.2.9_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:2.2.10_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:2.2.12_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:2.2.14_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:2.2.16_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”
ai-sn24:2.2.17_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:2.3.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, and has doubts about suffering in this way,
ai-sn24:2.3.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:2.3.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:3.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:3.1.3_0: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
ai-sn24:3.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:3.2.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:3.2.2_0: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-sn24:3.2.6_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:3.2.7_0: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-sn24:3.3.4_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:3.3.13_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:3.3.17_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:3.3.19_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:3.3.20_0: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”

ai-sn24:3.4.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:3.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:4.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:4.1.3_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—
ai-sn24:4.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”

ai-sn24:4.2.2_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—
ai-sn24:4.2.6_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:4.2.7_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—

ai-sn24:4.3.5_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—
ai-sn24:4.3.12_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:4.3.13_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—

ai-sn24:4.3.18_0: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’—
ai-sn24:4.4.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, and has doubts about suffering in this way,
ai-sn24:4.4.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:4.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:5.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:5.1.3_0: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings.
ai-sn24:5.1.3_1: There is no other world, no mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously.
ai-sn24:5.1.3_2: There are no ascetics and brahmins in the world who are practicing well, and they make it known.
ai-sn24:5.1.4_0: This person is made up of the four primary elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of air.
ai-sn24:5.1.5_0: The faculties are transferred to space.
ai-sn24:5.1.6_0: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
ai-sn24:5.1.7_0: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.
ai-sn24:5.1.9_0: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
ai-sn24:5.1.10_0: Giving is a doctrine for morons.
ai-sn24:5.1.11_0: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
ai-sn24:5.1.12_0: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death’?”
ai-sn24:5.1.13_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:5.2.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:5.2.3_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place,.’
ai-sn24:5.2.7_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:5.2.9_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place,.’
ai-sn24:5.3.4_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:5.3.6_0: when the body breaks up, after death, you won’t exist after death’?”
ai-sn24:5.3.13_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:5.3.15_0: when the body breaks up, after death, you won’t exist after death’?”
ai-sn24:5.3.17_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:5.3.19_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:5.3.21_0: and some who speak on the doctrine of others.
ai-sn24:5.3.22_0: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death’?”
ai-sn24:5.4.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, and has doubts about suffering in this way,
ai-sn24:5.4.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:5.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:6.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:6.1.3_0: the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, etc.
ai-sn24:6.1.4_0: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
ai-sn24:6.1.5_0: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges.
ai-sn24:6.1.5_1: killing and making others kill, destroying and making others destroy, tormenting and making others torment, and no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
ai-sn24:6.1.6_0: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges.
ai-sn24:6.1.6_1: While giving and sacrificial post, one does not possess the merit. Now there is no merit for the outcome of merit.
ai-sn24:6.1.7_0: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit’?”
ai-sn24:6.1.8_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:6.2.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:6.2.2_0: ‘The one who acts does a procedure of ejection.
ai-sn24:6.2.3_0: There is no merit or outcome of merit.’
ai-sn24:6.2.7_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:6.2.8_0: ‘The one who acts does a procedure of ejection.
ai-sn24:6.2.9_0: There is no merit or outcome of merit.’
ai-sn24:6.3.4_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:6.3.6_0: there is no merit or outcome of merit?”
ai-sn24:6.3.13_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:6.3.14_0: ‘The one who acts does a procedure of ejection.
ai-sn24:6.3.15_0: there is no merit or outcome of merit’?”
ai-sn24:6.3.17_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:6.3.19_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:6.3.20_0: ‘The one who acts does a procedure of ejection.
ai-sn24:6.3.21_0: there is no merit or outcome of merit’?”
ai-sn24:6.4.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, and has doubts about suffering in this way,
ai-sn24:6.4.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:6.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:7.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:7.1.3_0: ‘There is no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings.
ai-sn24:7.1.4_0: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
ai-sn24:7.1.5_0: There’s no cause or condition for the purification of sentient beings.
ai-sn24:7.1.6_0: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.
ai-sn24:7.1.7_0: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
ai-sn24:7.1.8_0: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth’?”
ai-sn24:7.1.9_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:7.2.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:7.2.2_0: There is no cause or condition for the origination that is the reason why there’s no cause or condition for the cessation of action ...
ai-sn24:7.2.7_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:7.2.8_0: There is no cause or condition for the origination that is the reason why there’s no cause or condition for the cessation of action ...
ai-sn24:7.3.4_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”
ai-sn24:7.3.5_0: There is no cause or condition for the origination that is the reason why there’s no cause or condition for the cessation of action ...
ai-sn24:7.3.13_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:7.3.14_0: There is no cause or condition for the origination that is the reason why there’s no cause or condition for the cessation of action ...
ai-sn24:7.3.17_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:7.3.19_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:7.3.20_0: There is no cause or condition for the origination of there ...
ai-sn24:7.4.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, and has doubts about suffering in this way,
ai-sn24:7.4.1_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn24:7.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-sn24:8.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:8.1.3_0: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
ai-sn24:8.1.4_0: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other.
ai-sn24:8.1.4_1: They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other.
ai-sn24:8.1.5_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-sn24:8.1.6_0: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
ai-sn24:8.1.7_0: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
ai-sn24:8.1.8_0: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other.
ai-sn24:8.1.8_1: They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other.
ai-sn24:8.1.9_0: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.
ai-sn24:8.1.10_0: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.
ai-sn24:8.1.11_0: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,90 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven embryos without attachments. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven winds, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 7000 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
ai-sn24:8.1.12_0: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little”—for that cannot be.
ai-sn24:8.1.13_0: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.
ai-sn24:8.1.14_0: It’s like when it takes a string to a mouse
ai-sn24:8.1.15_0: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering’?”
ai-sn24:8.1.16_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:8.2.1_0: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
ai-sn24:8.2.2_0: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator,
ai-sn24:8.2.7_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:8.2.8_0: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator,
ai-sn24:8.3.4_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”
ai-sn24:8.3.5_0: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator,
ai-sn24:8.3.8_0: “What has you seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: that is impermanent?”
ai-sn24:8.3.10_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
ai-sn24:8.3.11_0: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator,
ai-sn24:8.3.12_0: Could they make an end to suffering?”

ai-sn24:13.0.3_0: 13. The Soul and the Body Are Identical
ai-sn24:13.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:13.1.3_0: ‘The soul and the body are identical’?” ...
ai-sn24:13.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:14.0.3_0: Then someone else substance could there be another’s disciples
ai-sn24:14.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:14.1.3_0: ‘The soul and the body are different things’?” ...

ai-sn24:15.1.6_0: The group of fifteen are finished.
ai-sn24:16.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:16.1.3_0: ‘A Realized One doesn’t exist after death’?” ...
ai-sn24:16.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn24:17.0.3_0: Seeing this, a Realized One became Patience.
ai-sn24:17.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does view arise:
ai-sn24:17.1.3_0: ‘A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death’?” ...
ai-sn24:17.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”

ai-sn24:18.4.1_0: “Mendicants, when a noble disciple has given up these things, they’ve given up doubts regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
ai-sn24:18.4.2_0: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”

ai-sn24:71.2.11_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:71.2.13_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn24:71.2.14_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:71.2.21_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:71.2.23_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn24:71.2.24_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:71.3.1_0: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near:
ai-sn24:71.3.1_1: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn24:71.3.2_0: Any kind of feeling at all ...
ai-sn24:71.3.3_0: Any kind of perception at all ...
ai-sn24:71.3.4_0: Any kind of choices at all ...
ai-sn24:71.3.5_0: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, *all* consciousness—with right understanding:
ai-sn24:71.3.5_1: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn24:71.4.2_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn24:71.4.3_0: First the first part of the body.

ai-sn24:96.2.6_0: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
ai-sn24:96.2.7_0: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death.’
ai-sn24:96.3.4_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:96.3.6_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn24:96.3.7_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:96.3.14_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn24:96.3.16_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn24:96.3.17_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn24:96.4.1_0: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near:
ai-sn24:96.4.1_1: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn24:96.4.2_0: Any kind of feeling at all ...
ai-sn24:96.4.3_0: Any kind of perception at all ...
ai-sn24:96.4.4_0: Any kind of choices at all ...
ai-sn24:96.4.5_0: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near:
ai-sn24:96.4.5_1: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn24:96.5.1_0: When they see this, the learned noble disciples are repelled by form, repelled by feeling, repelled by perception, repelled by intentional activities, and repelled by consciousness.
ai-sn24:96.5.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn24:96.5.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn24:96.6.3_0: The third section for breaking the six sentences
ai-sn24:96.6.5_0: The Linked Discourses on views are complete.
